title: William Foster MacNeece Foster
text:
<a href="Air%20Vice%20Marshal">Air Vice Marshal</a> William Foster MacNeece Foster, (21 August 1889 – 28 March 1978) was a senior <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> officer who was a member of the <a href="Combined%20Chiefs%20of%20Staff">Combined Chiefs of Staff</a> from 1942 to 1943. He later became a member of <a href="Oxford%20City%20Council">Oxford City Council</a> and <a href="Mayors%20of%20Oxford">Lord Mayor of Oxford</a>.
Early life.
Born William Foster MacNeece on 21 August 1889 in <a href="Aldershot">Aldershot</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>, England, he was the eldest son of Colonel T. F. MacNeece RAMC. He was educated at <a href="Cheltenham%20College">Cheltenham College</a>, an <a href="Independent%20school%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">independent school</a> located in <a href="Cheltenham">Cheltenham</a>, <a href="Gloucestershire">Gloucestershire</a>, England. He later assumed the surname of Foster by way of royal licence in 1927.
Military career.
Having attended the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>, Foster was <a href="Officer%20%28armed%20forces%29">commissioned</a> on 6 February 1909 into the <a href="Queen%27s%20Own%20Royal%20West%20Kent%20Regiment">Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment</a> as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a>. He was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> on 2 February 1912. Having trained as a pilot, on 31 October 1913, he was awarded <a href="Royal%20Aero%20Club">Royal Aero Club</a> (RAeC) Aviator Certificate number 671. On 28 April 1914, he was transferred to the reserve of the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Corps">Royal Flying Corps</a>.
With the outbreak of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, Foster would go on to serve in Europe. In 1914, he was a pilot in <a href="No.%203%20Squadron%20RFC">No. 3 Squadron RFC</a>, conducting <a href="air%20reconnaissance">air reconnaissance</a> over <a href="France">France</a>. He was a <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> when, on 9 September 1915, he was appointed a <a href="flight%20commander">flight commander</a> in the Royal Flying Corps. On 5 December 1916, as a <a href="temporary%20rank">temporary</a> <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a>, he was appointed <a href="Wing%20commander%20%28rank%29">wing commander</a> and made a temporary <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a>. Foster was awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) in the <a href="1917%20New%20Year%20Honours">1917 New Year Honours</a>.
On 16 January 1919, he joined the <a href="Air%20Ministry">Air Ministry</a> as a <a href="Staff%20Officer">Staff Officer</a>, 1st Class. Foster became <a href="Air%20Officer%20Commanding">Air Officer Commanding</a> No. 1 Air Defence Group RAF in 1929 and Air Officer Commanding No. 6 (Bomber) Group RAF in 1939. He served in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> in this role before becoming a member of the <a href="Combined%20Chiefs%20of%20Staff">Combined Chiefs of Staff</a> in 1942, Head of Inter-Service Liaison Committee in <a href="Washington%20D.%20C.">Washington D. C.</a> in 1943 and Head of the RAF Training Mission in China in 1944.
Later life.
After the Second World War, Foster settled in <a href="Oxford">Oxford</a>. He served on the city council, and was Lord Mayor in 1966/7. He died on 28 March 1978.
Personal life.
Foster married Jean Bruce in 1928. Together they had two daughters.
